 All the ads and trailers from the big game

Winners, snubs and surprises from music's major night

Netflix, Paramount Skydance face off

Disney's new structure ensures Josh D'Amaro will lean heavily on Dana Walden's veteran skill and relationships in Hollywood's creative community.

Wall Street seemed to prefer D'Amaro, who has knowledge of parks and attractions, areas of Disney's business that are growing.

“Saturday Night Live” has its Emmy-worthy star. 

 “SNL” featured performer Ashley Padilla has found her groove during the show’s 51st season, emerging as an early…

The cast of “Saturday Night Live U.K.” has been unveiled.

 Hammed Animashaun, Ayoade Bamgboye, Larry Dean, Celeste Dring, George Fouracres, Ania Magliano, Annabel…

In February 2011, Jeffrey Epstein was in need of an assistant. He asked his friend Barry Josephson, a producer of the Fox show “Bones,” if he knew of any “amazing women&#8221…

Savannah Guthrie posted an emotional video to her Instagram on Wednesday evening in which she and her two siblings, Annie and Cameron, addressed the kidnapper of her…

The two discuss 'Wicked: For Good,' what makes them cry and loving 'The Waterboy.'

The two on their life-changing 'Mummy' friendship, loneliness and learning to stop trying so hard.

A Variety and iHeartRadio Podcast

Rachel McAdams thrives on a desert island in Sam Raimi's twisted survival thriller. Going back to his roots, Raimi wickedly flips the dynamic between a number cruncher and her nightmare boss.

In a mockumentary that plays it straight, Charli xcx is teamed with a doofus director (Alexander Skarsgård) who wants to clean up her image. But why would any version of Charli xcx say yes?

Brett Ratner's First Lady documentary is a cheeseball infomercial of staggering inertia. There's no drama to a film that should have been called "Day of the Living Tradwife."

The first feature by the YouTube gamer personality Markiplier is a murky sci-fi horror tale that confines us to a midget submarine. The claustrophobic perils are plentiful but wear thin.

'Interior Chinatown' Struggles to Turn an Allegorical Novel Into a Show

HBO Prequel Series 'Dune: Prophecy' Capably Tailors the Epic Franchise to Television

Taylor Sheridan's 'Landman' Gives the West Texas Oil Fields the 'Yellowstone' Treatment

Eddie Redmayne and Lashana Lynch's 'The Day of the Jackal' Is an Exhilarating Assassin Thriller

Billie Eilish and producer Finneas keep up their winning streak with a surprising and intimate third album.

Childish Gambino's latest is a masterpiece, and a kaleidoscopic showcase for his seemingly endless talents.

Vince Staples searches for light on his new album, his most vulnerable project to date.

Dua Lipa's new album is a joyous blast of pop savvy.

Sam Gold's production is an actorly face-off between Jeremy Strong and Michael Imperioli, but the script ultimately let's the audience off the hook.

Patricia Clarkson gives a luminous performance in an otherwise uneven revival of Eugene O'Neill's family drama.

The stage adaptation has escapism, enchantment and heart, all elevated to new, literal heights that blend theater and cirque.

Popular on Variety

 
 
 

 

 
 
 ‘Joybubbles’ Director Rachael Morrison and Editors Bradford Thomason and Patrick Lawrence on Their Retro Phone Hacker Doc
 
 
 

 
 
 Perfection is rarely achieved in movies, but this heaven-sent concert doc hits the sweet spot. Over two days in January 1972, the Queen of Soul, Aretha Franklin — she was 29 at the time — sweeps into the New Temple Missionary Baptist Church in Watts in front of a congregation and testifies to God in song. The blessed thing took nearly half a century to come out because director Sydney Pollack failed to sync the image with the sound. Then digital angels stepped in, and glory, glory, hallelujah!

You can opt-out of the sale and sharing of your personal information by using this toggle switch. As a Virginia, Utah, Colorado and Connecticut consumer, you have the right to opt-out from the sale of your personal data and the processing of your personal data for targeted advertising. You can opt-out of the sale of your personal data and targeted advertising by using this toggle switch. For more information on your rights as a United States consumer see our privacy notice.

dtliExcerpt: Simon Neil's dramedy about a middle-aged man's midlife crisis feels overly familiar and schematic, despite some winning performances.

This balanced negative/positive assessment suggests mixed reception. Single excerpt warning applies - confidence is low. | GPT-4o: The excerpt notes that the play feels 'overly familiar and schematic,' which suggests a lack of originality or impact, but acknowledges 'some winning performances.' This indicates a mixed review, with neither a strong recommendation nor a strong discouragement. | Gemini: The review notes the play is "overly familiar and schematic" but acknowledges "winning performances." This suggests a mixed experience, with some redeeming qualities but significant flaws. Given that it is only one excerpt, confidence is low. | Kimi: The excerpt criticizes the material as derivative and mechanical while acknowledging good acting, suggesting a middling assessment. With only one curated excerpt available, the full verdict is unclear.

rejectionReasoning: claude: This appears to be a website navigation page or content feed with multiple unrelated articles about Super Bowl ads, Disney executives, and various entertainment projects - not a theater review.; openai: The text consists of unrelated content about various entertainment topics and does not contain any review of a Broadway show.; gemini: This appears to be a listing of various articles and news items, not a review of a specific show.; kimi: The text provided is a jumbled collection of entertainment news headlines, navigation elements, and snippets about various topics (Super Bowl, films, albums, TV shows) rather than a coherent review article of a specific Broadway production. It appears to be scraped webpage content containing multiple unrelated articles and menu items.
